awd_titl_txt: Tailorable, responsive, and morphologically-tunable plasmonic chiroptical nanoparticle superstructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Summary
The study and control of chiral nanoscale materials are rapidly growing areas of research. A chiral material is something that cannot be superimposed on its mirror image, like a left and a right hand. Chiral nanomaterials have the potential to serve as sensors for disease markers, as catalysts for important industrial chemical processes, and as components in optical devices as mundane as a camera and as exotic as an invisibility cloak. This research, which is jointly supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program and the Biomaterials program at NSF, focuses on the development and advancement of chiral nanoscale materials assembled from gold nanoparticles. The researchers at the University of Pittsburgh advance fundamental insights into the construction of these materials and optimization of the unique optical properties that underscore their practical promise. This fundamental research involves participation from a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate researchers, who communicate their discoveries in scientific publications and presentations, as well as in science demonstrations for the general public. Additionally, to increase diversity in the chemical sciences the principle investigator engages in targeted recruiting activities.

Technical Summary
Recent years have witnessed the emergence of a wide variety of chiral nanoparticle superstructures that exhibit unique plasmonic chiroptical properties. To propel this field forward and to ultimately realize the technological promise of these materials, research efforts must focus on the following challenges: i) deliberate optimization of plasmonic chiroptical properties; ii) design and preparation of dynamic and responsive plasmonic chiroptical materials; and iii) development of sustainable and scalable syntheses and efficient means of material manipulation to allow for their more widespread study and use. The central goal of this research, which is jointly supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program and the Biomaterials program at NSF, is to address these challenges by leveraging molecular methods for constructing nanoparticle superstructures that rely on peptide conjugate molecules to direct nanoparticle synthesis and assembly. The PI and his group: i) elucidate how the molecular composition and structure of peptide conjugate molecules affects the assembly, structure, and properties of helical gold nanoparticle superstructures; ii) develop new approaches for fabricating photo-responsive helical nanoparticle superstructures exhibiting 'on/off' plasmonic chiroptical behavior which is coupled to reversible molecular transformations; iii) establish strategies for controlling the length and surface chemistry of helical nanoparticle superstructures; and iv) develop new, sustainable approaches for preparing helical nanoparticle superstructures. The findings illuminate how molecular-level alterations to peptide precursors translates into dramatic nanoscale alterations to the assembly, metrics, and properties of helical nanoparticle superstructures. The transformational impact of the research lies in the ability to precisely control the structure of nano- to microscale materials using molecular chemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The color of our eyes; the shape of a leaf; the nanoscale structure of a diatom’s silica frustule.  These observable attributes all originate from a unique molecular coding within an organism’s genome. Small changes to the molecular coding can dramatically change observable attributes. Indeed, in Nature, the structure and compositions of molecules are translated across length scales and manifest as changes in properties and function. Inspired by this natural paradigm, we created a molecular code for controlling the assembly of inorganic nanoparticles into unique morphologically-tunable and responsive nano- and microscale nanoparticle superstructures, wherein small and rational alterations to the code can be used to carefully and deliberately adjust the structure, metrics, and properties of the superstructure. 

Intellectual Merit:

The molecular constructs that serve as our molecular code are amphiphilic peptide conjugate molecules consisting of a short peptide modified with a hydrophobic tail which assemble in water into various structures including spherical micelles, vesicles, and 1-D fibers. The peptide is selected from a class of ‘biomineralization’ peptides, which have a special ability to bind to certain inorganic surfaces, such as gold. Therefore, the peptide conjugate can both assemble in aqueous media and attach to inorganic nanoparticle surfaces. The peptide conjugate assemblies act as a scaffold for assembling nanoparticles.  

In this research, we showed how gold binding peptide conjugate molecules could be used to prepare and systematically tune the structure and properties of gold nanoparticle single helices. Gold nanoparticle single helices consist of gold nanoparticles arranged along a screw axis into a helical array.  They exhibit unusual optical properties, in particular plasmonic circular dichroism, which make them promising metamaterials for sensing, labeling, and optical applications. The properties of these materials depend on numerous factors, including the helical pitch and nanoparticle size. Through this research, we showed that the peptide amino acid sequence could be adjusted to control structural factors such as particle size, helical pitch, and helical morphology (e.g., single helices vs. double helices). Coupling experiment with computations, we developed foundational understanding of how peptide sequence affects peptide-gold nanoparticle interactions and how these interactions can be correlated to particle size and dimensions and ultimately helical morphology.

We developed a robust understanding of how the peptide conjugate molecules direct the assembly of nanoparticles, identifying the molecular components of the conjugates that govern assembly and those that govern nanoparticle binding. Using this information, we designed special ‘modulator’ molecules that significantly affect peptide conjugate and nanoparticle superstructure assembly kinetics. We used these molecules to carefully control the length of helical nanoparticle superstructures, which enabled production of colloidal helical samples having uniform lengths. We also modulated the stability of these helices by controlling particle dimensions, leading to development of helices that can withstand elevated temperatures and the presence of various molecular denaturants. Both helix length and stability are critically important for downstream practical applications.

Finally, we designed and developed new classes of photoresponsive peptide conjugate molecules for constructing dynamic and photoresponsive nanoparticle superstructures. We successfully identified peptide conjugates that direct the assembly of linear nanoparticle superstructures that reversibly transform into spherical superstructures upon irradiation with light. Such controllable dynamic behavior could be useful for the development of novel theranostic materials.

In summary, we developed peptide-based methods for controlling nanoparticle assembly and specifically studied and identified fundamental atomic and molecular underpinnings which control nano-microscale structure of nanoparticle superstructures. Our results are significant because they chart a roadmap for leveraging the molecular composition and structure of peptides to finely control structure and properties of materials at much longer length scales.

Broader Impacts:

We used this research as a highly interdisciplinary training ground for undergraduate and graduate student researchers.  We engaged in outreach activities with local and regional high schools to raise awareness about STEM research and encourage participation. This engagement included scientific demonstrations, lab tours, and research presentations.
